posts.name: Kaitlyn
posts.cooked:
My team’s off season project is redesigning our grippers.  I’m pretty happy with my design, but there’s always room for improvement ¯_(ツ)_/¯ Any input is appreciated

posts.name: Nathan Shepherd
posts.cooked: Is there a particular reason for having one run of chain when everything else is belts?

posts.name: Sean Stevens
posts.cooked:
Hi. Great start on a redesign. There were many fantastic robots that use very similar designs this season so you are on a good track.

A few things I notice that could be improved

I’m fairly sure your motor belt pulleys are not made for the same belt pitch.

The plate structure becomes relatively thin between the motor and the center protrusion. When you run into a wall this is where the intake will break. I would not include those indentations at the back.

You should consider using the same thickness material for both the top and bottom plate. This makes it easier to make spares and doesn’t entice one plate to fail before the other.

Consider putting the second stage of your motor reduction between the plates rather than directly on top of the prior stage.

You need some kind of spacer that holds the 2 main plates apart from each other.

No specific recommendation here but I think you should consider ways to make it more compact. It looks taller than it needs to be.

posts.name: Marshall Hamon
posts.cooked:
Just to clarify on what seans341 said, the pitch of the pulley on the neo 550 is probably GT2 (if you’re using Rev’s neo 550 pinion pulley ) while it looks like you’re also using HTD5 pulleys on the hex shafts. The rest of the advice here is solid.

I don’t understand the necessity of the hex axle that takes the belt input from the neo 550 and drives the large wheels that are closer together. If you’re trying to achieve a reduction, you might be better off using a planetary gearbox, either Versaplanetary or MAXPlanetary . These gearboxes can have hex outputs, which you can either have directly drive the large wheels that are closer together, or you can drive it indirectly in some other way (but with two pulleys of matching pitch). It should also be more compact, be more adjustable, and weigh less.

Small thing, but since your wheels are turning at the same RPM, and have different diameters, they’ll have slightly different surface speeds. This will probably not be a huge problem with handling game pieces, but it might things slightly less efficient.

A way to address this problem while making the whole thing more compact is to have one belt loop drive the entire set of pulleys. You can have smaller pulleys on the ends, and larger pulleys in the center to keep it tensioned.

This portion on the top plate is likely to be a weak point and the gripper will twist of there on impact, even in polycarb is used.

All the shafts should be filled with 3d printed spacers to prevent the pulleys from wandering.

If the plates are to be made out of polycarbonate, you should add some method to retain the bearings so they don’t pop out when impacted.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Can you provide pictures with the cone and cube, in the predicted collection spot?

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
In addition to the excellent remarks by the previous commenters, here are a couple of other thoughts I have:

You could probably save a lot of weight and complexity by using gears instead of belts/sprockets for your reductions - at the very least, it makes things more compact and cuts the part count.

The second stage reduction can be brought in under the top plate, reducing the overall height of the manipulator. If you put the motor on some standoffs, you can also bring the first stage between the plates, but that’s less valuable.

I’ll disagree with @Zekrim on a few points: it’s not mandatory that you use a gearbox (though the MAXplanetary is quite compact, making it a decent application). Additionally, using one big belt run adds a lot of complexity and points where the belt can easily skip.

If you publish the model as a STEP or similar, we can also check other details, like sprocket and belt spacing.

There’s no top view for me to check against, so I can’t tell how much the small 2" wheels stick out from the plate. It looks like they don’t stick out much at all, which is bad, because they’ll squeeze to the point that the cone rubs along the plate.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
You probably don’t want to run chain this fast. Neo 550 on a 4:1 belt reduction puts this at a 2,750PRM (assuming you’re running 12:48, although as others pointed out you may have mismatching pitches), Going to a 16 tooth sprocket you’re chain moves 4" / rev so you’re running the chain at ~916 ft / min which is pretty fast for roller chain. At this speed chain tends to shed all its grease rather quickly and then you’ll see sprocket wear and increased friction. In industry they would put an oil bath for a chain running this fast to lubricate it. You can probably get away with it for a while, this is FRC after all, it only has to work 2.5 minutes at a time, but you may have maintenance issues with it over a season.

In general, I would avoid chains on an intake.

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: Lots of good feedback.  Two questions I have: What keeps your bearings from popping out?  How are the hex axles fastened?

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: I’d suggest using a ultra planetary, not a max planetary and then 3d printing an adapter.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
OP, This is more of a prototyping thing vs design thing, but is the surface speed mismatch of the wheels desirable? You have room play with pulleys to get the surface speed of the large wheels closer to the smalls.

ClayTownR:

Additionally, using one big belt run adds a lot of complexity and points where the belt can easily skip.

I was thinking about this, I am honestly not sure if I like lots of little short belt runs in this application or some timing belt, non-industry-standard FRC voodoo wraps better. Considering you probably want to drive the wheels pretty fast I am inclined to avoid FRC twisted timing belts or massive serpentine situations, but it is worth a head scratch imo.

The occasional skip should not be an issue as nothing needs to be clocked to eachother, may even be desirable to save wear on the gearbox (pulleys easily inspected). But your right, belt skipping is likely a “bug that acts like a feature”.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Artist interpretation of chain lube and gampiece:

You can get all the feedback possible on screenshots of CAD, but you can never really know how good the design is without testing it. Make some prototypes, and don’t be gentle testing it. Make sure the geometry of the wheels works well, figure out your current limits and other software, and don’t be afraid to break it. When it does break, or when you find any flaws, fix them.

</programmer take>

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A sneaky idea (that we actually built and tested) is to have a series of plastic tubes on aluminum spacers between the rollers.  The SINGLE belt zig-zags between the roller pulleys and the rollers to get a small wrap angle.  Make one of the rollers with a 3DP skin on it and adjust that diameter for belt tension.  MUCH simpler than a festival of belts. I wish I had a photo…

posts.name: Arjunb
posts.cooked: I may be missing something, but the middle 2 sets of wheels seem redundant and may add unnecessary complexity(and weight).

posts.name: BCR-Jim
posts.cooked: Wondering if you can provide a picture of this setup, or a link to the CAD?  I having a difficult time picturing this setup.

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked: This is what is being described, except they have a 3D printed cover slipped over one or more sets of idler bearings so you can adjust that outer diameter to dial in the belt tension without having to scrap the entire plate.

link_counts.title: Designing with WCP belts and pulleys Part 3: Advanced complex belt paths - YouTube

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Yeah, that!  NIce!  We used MUCH less belt wrap, though.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: I do like your suggestion of just leaving space and adjust the OD of a idler (non tooth side) to fine tune tension. I feel like this is the best way to tension on something that could take a hit (vs slots/cams anyway).

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
ClayTownR:

You could probably save a lot of weight and complexity by using gears instead of belts/sprockets for your reductions - at the very least, it makes things more compact and cuts the part count.

A tip for the up and coming engineers in our program:  if implementing this advice, remember that pulleys attached by a belt rotate in the same direction, whereas mated gears rotate in opposite directions.  In this case, on each side of the intake, you want the wheels to spin in the same direction, so belts are a good choice.  Gears can be used too, but you need to add an idler gear in between each gear that drives a wheel, so that the wheels spin in the same direction.

On reverse side of this tip:  because you presumably want the two sides of your intake to spin in opposite directions, you can use a single pair of gears to create the two directions of spin, and then use belts on each side to keep the side internally consistent.

links.title: Designing with WCP belts and pulleys Part 3: Advanced complex belt paths - YouTube
